text: Did anybody switch from a mainly async job to a sync (meeting-heavy) one? Did it work out? How do you handle the "culture shock"?

elements.text: Did anybody switch from a mainly async job to a sync (meeting-heavy) one? Did it work out? How do you handle the "culture shock"?

text: Was it this? <https://peakfreelance.com/blog/freelance-writing-rates/>

attachments.fallback: Peak Freelance: Freelance Writing Rates: How Much to Charge for Freelance Writing Services (New Data for 2022)
attachments.text: In this post, we’re going to use a survey sent to 213 freelance writers to determine the average freelance writing rates. Using that data, we’ll answer a question we’ve heard quite a bit in the industry. What should I charge? Of course, a new writer isn’t going to charge $1,000+ per article
attachments.title: Freelance Writing Rates: How Much to Charge for Freelance Writing Services (New Data for 2022)

elements.text: Was it this?

text: I did the opposite when I went out on my own, and then back again a bit when I hired my team. Biggest suggestion is to get clearance from your boss to have certain days or afternoons or whatever where you don't have meetings (obv requests from execs etc can trump it) so you can focus. Pitch it as needing time for focused work to do your job effectively for the good of the company.

elements.text: I did the opposite when I went out on my own, and then back again a bit when I hired my team. Biggest suggestion is to get clearance from your boss to have certain days or afternoons or whatever where you don't have meetings (obv requests from execs etc can trump it) so you can focus. Pitch it as needing time for focused work to do your job effectively for the good of the company.

text: Reading The Four Hour Work Week chapters about Elimination will help

elements.text: Reading The Four Hour Work Week chapters about Elimination will help

text:
Hi everyone! I am a content marketer actively applying for remote content marketing roles at tech companies, mainly US based. I would love to know any tips that you may have in regards to standing out on my resume. 
Unfortunately, I have not been getting interview callbacks for my applications despite being well qualified for the roles. This prompted me to do some research to figure out the right format and language to use for both my CV and cover letter. I am based in Kenya, and would like to know what US companies look for when it comes to resume applications?

elements.text:
Hi everyone! I am a content marketer actively applying for remote content marketing roles at tech companies, mainly US based. I would love to know any tips that you may have in regards to standing out on my resume. 
Unfortunately, I have not been getting interview callbacks for my applications despite being well qualified for the roles. This prompted me to do some research to figure out the right format and language to use for both my CV and cover letter. I am based in Kenya, and would like to know what US companies look for when it comes to resume applications?

text: You may not be getting interview callbacks for the simple reason that you are located in Kenya. Are you certain the companies you’re applying for can/want to hire employees in your location?

elements.text: You may not be getting interview callbacks for the simple reason that you are located in Kenya. Are you certain the companies you’re applying for can/want to hire employees in your location?

text: For example, my company can only hire folks in Canada, the US, and India. As a hiring manager, I automatically disqualify anyone who isn’t located in one of those three countries no matter how qualified they are because unfortunately I won’t be able to hire them. The location is clearly indicated on the job description, but people from all over the world still apply for some reason.

elements.text: For example, my company can only hire folks in Canada, the US, and India. As a hiring manager, I automatically disqualify anyone who isn’t located in one of those three countries no matter how qualified they are because unfortunately I won’t be able to hire them. The location is clearly indicated on the job description, but people from all over the world still apply for some reason.

text: Agree with <@URAV154AV>. Relatively few companies are equipped to deal with business-, insurance-, tax-related issues involved in hiring a one-off person in a country in which they don't already operate. That's related to companies that follow laws and business regulations. That would have nothing to do with someone’s qualifications.

elements.text: Agree with

. Relatively few companies are equipped to deal with business-, insurance-, tax-related issues involved in hiring a one-off person in a country in which they don't already operate. That's related to companies that follow laws and business regulations. That would have nothing to do with someone’s qualifications.

text: <@URAV154AV> <@U02VBUQR0E7>  Thanks for sharing this. However, the roles I apply to are open to hiring from all over the globe. I am sure to check the job description for information on time zones or regions that the company is hiring.

elements.text: Thanks for sharing this. However, the roles I apply to are open to hiring from all over the globe. I am sure to check the job description for information on time zones or regions that the company is hiring.

text: thank you <@U034H601T7X>, that is very good advice :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: thank you
, that is very good advice

text: you’re welcome! good luck.

elements.text: you’re welcome! good luck.

text: I'm not sure if this is the best advice, but one potential workaround is to apply or work for roles that are under an 'agency'. Not sure if this will work for you as you're based out of Kenya, but an acquaintance of mine was hired by Nike through a hiring agency (she's Canadian).

elements.text: I'm not sure if this is the best advice, but one potential workaround is to apply or work for roles that are under an 'agency'. Not sure if this will work for you as you're based out of Kenya, but an acquaintance of mine was hired by Nike through a hiring agency (she's Canadian).

text: Hey! We're currently hiring for a tech content marketing agency (not in the US though!) so I feel like my head is full of CVs and covering letters. Do you want to DM me yours? I'd be happy to give you quick feedback if you'd like.

text: I liberally block off chunks of my time so meetings can’t be scheduled (including during my lunch hour)!

text: Yeah, I block out times for editing  and content planning when I know I'll do my best work at those tasks. I also generally try to be the person who schedules one on one meetings so I can dictate my specific preferences. :joy:

elements.text: Yeah, I block out times for editing  and content planning when I know I'll do my best work at those tasks. I also generally try to be the person who schedules one on one meetings so I can dictate my specific preferences.

text:
Congrats <@U030U5XJG68>! How's the new role going?

I recently put together an internal training course for a client's business. I modeled my training off the Google manager training (and customized it for my client's internal company culture).

Very insightful.

Definitely worth a look - <https://rework.withgoogle.com/guides/managers-develop-and-support-managers/steps/review-googles-new-manager-training/>

attachments.fallback: re:Work -  Guide: Develop and support managers
attachments.text: Growing and training managers, with the help of Google's training workshop, can help build a culture of great management.
attachments.title: re:Work -  Guide: Develop and support managers
